title: The Louisiana Purchase
subtitle: Doubling the Nation (1803)
narrator: Marie, age 14, daughter of a French trader in New Orleans, 1803

sections.title: A Territory Changes Hands
sections.summary: I'm Marie, fourteen, living in New Orleans. My city has been French, then Spanish, now French again, and today I learned we're about to become American! The news arrived: President Jefferson has purchased all of Louisiana from Napoleon for $15 million.

sections.title: New Opportunities
sections.summary: The Purchase solves major problems for America. We needed access to New Orleans—the mouth of the Mississippi River where western farmers ship their goods. France controlling it was dangerous.

sections.title: Jefferson's Dilemma
sections.summary: My father explains President Jefferson's predicament. Jefferson has always preached strict construction—the federal government should only exercise powers explicitly granted in the Constitution. He's criticized Hamilton and the Federalists for loose interpretation, claiming they stretch the Constitu...

sections.title: Life in New Orleans
sections.summary: My city, New Orleans, is unlike anywhere else in America. We're French and Spanish, Catholic and Creole. We speak French more than English.

sections.title: The Price of Expansion
sections.summary: While Americans celebrate acquiring vast new territory, few ask about the people already living there. Tens of thousands of Native peoples call Louisiana home: Osage, Caddo, Choctaw, Chickasaw, and dozens of other nations. France just sold their land without their consent.

vocabulary.definition: The 1803 purchase of Louisiana Territory from France for $15 million, doubling U.S. size.
French leader who sold Louisiana to the United States to fund wars and prevent British seizure.
Strategic port city at the mouth of the Mississippi River, crucial for western American trade.
Major river system that western farmers used to ship goods, now entirely under U.S. control.
The belief that the Constitution should be interpreted literally, limiting federal power to what's explicitly stated.
Jefferson's vision of America expanding westward as a nation of independent farmers.
